math_problem: A person starts at position (0,0,0) in the space {0,1}^3. Each minute, one of the three coordinates is chosen uniformly at random and flipped (0 becomes 1, 1 becomes 0). After an even number of minutes, the position always has an even number of 1's. In terms of $k$, for $k>0$ how likely is he to be back where he started after $2 k$ minutes? Instead of determining the return probability as a function of $k$, simply find $m = q_0 + 9/4$, where $q_0$ is the initial deviation of the return probability from its limiting value derived from the recurrence relation for returns to the origin. Compute $\int_{0}^{\pi} \frac{2 \sin \theta + m \cos \theta - m}{13 \cos \theta - 5} \,\mathrm{d} \theta$.

A3379: Mathematics -> Applied Mathematics -> Statistics -> Probability -> Counting Methods -> Combinations

A953: Mathematics -> Calculus -> Integral Calculus -> Techniques of Integration -> Single-variable
